body.p: The Amateur Company of the Guild of Literature and ArtFor the Prospectus of the Guild of Literature and Art, April 1851, see Pilgrim Letters 6, p. 852 (Appendix D); its aim was to help artists and writers with annuities as well as grants for members in need and their widows, an insurance scheme and houses for needy or retired writers and artists, built on Bulwer Lytton’s estate at Knebworth, Hertfordshire. (after doing wonders at Manchester and Liverpool)The Amateurs performed Lytton’s Not so Bad as we Seem, and Mark Lemon’s Mr Nightingale’s Diary, heavily revised by CD, on 11, 13 and 14 Feb 52 at Manchester and Liverpool with great success. are going to dine with their Manager here on Monday the 1st of MarchCD had invited the “whole company, and the Artists who painted the Scenes”, as well as the Duke of Devonshire, in whose house Lytton’s play had been first performed (Pilgrim Letters 6, pp. 322, 602). at a quarter past six. It will give me great pleasure if you will join the party.Roberts went: see also Pilgrim Letters 6, pp. 614-5.
